justification: The article states: "We collected the following questionnaires … Ten Item Personality Inventory (Gosling et al., 2003)" indicating that TIPI was used to assess Big Five personality traits.
In the psychographic measures section the authors list "Domain-Specific Risk-Taking Scale (Weber et al., 2002)" as one of the questionnaires administered to measure risk-taking.
The text includes "Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (Patton et al., 1995)" among the questionnaires, showing that impulsiveness was measured with this scale.
The authors note they used the "Self-Report Altruism Scale (Rushton et al., 1981)" to capture altruism.
The paper reports employing the "Grit Scale (Duckworth et al., 2009)" as a questionnaire, linking it to the construct of grit.
The psychographic battery included the "Satisfaction With Life Scale (Arrindell et al., 1999)", indicating this scale measured life satisfaction.
The list of questionnaires contains "Maximization Scale short (Nenkov et al., 2008)", showing it was used to assess maximization tendencies.

measured_by: 7-point Likert self-rating of likelihood to perform each behavior phrase
justification: Participants rated statements of the form "Relative to others, I am likely to X" on a 1–7 Likert scale, which operationalized their behavioral propensity toward each action.
